thread.title: UCLA: Rosen helps Bruins end two-game slide
thread.title_full: UCLA: Rosen helps Bruins end two-game slide - Press Enterprise

author: JOEY KAUFMAN
title: UCLA: Rosen helps Bruins end two-game slide
text:
By JOEY KAUFMAN / STAFF WRITER
Published: Oct. 22, 2015 Updated: Oct. 23, 2015 12:35 a.m. PASADENA – Less than three weeks ago in the same stadium, UCLA’s offense looked overwhelmed, slow and out of sync, unable to muster much against an aggressive Arizona State group.
Its return trip to the Rose Bowl for a Thursday night contest against Cal, a crossroads point in its season following consecutive losses to the Sun Devils and Stanford, ended up being quite the contrast.
Debuting their black-and-shiny-gold “City” uniforms, the Bruins amassed 572 yards of total offense, toppling No.20 Cal in convincing fashion, 40-24. They never trailed beyond an early 3-0 deficit following the Golden Bears’ opening drive and led by double digits for most of the night.
The Bruins (5-2, 2-2 Pac-12) had lost consecutive October games for the third consecutive season, including a 56-35 thrashing at Stanford last Thursday that dropped the Bruins out of the Top 25.
“We found a way to pull out of it (before),” UCLA coach Jim Mora said, “and we did again.”
Quarterback Josh Rosen delivered arguably his best performance to date in front of an announced crowd of 57,046.
The 18-year-old freshman completed 34 of 47 passes for 399 yards, three touchdowns and no interceptions.
His 34 completions are a school single-game record, surpassing a mark shared by Brett Hundley, who completed 33 in a nonconference game against Memphis last season, and Richard Brehaut, who did it at Arizona State in 2010.
“He has a lot of confidence because he’s prepared,” Mora said. “He’s a rare kid.”
Rosen was clicking from the get-go.
After senior kicker Ka’imi Fairbairn tied the game following a 44-yard field goal on the Bruins’ opening drive, Rosen had a nice follow-up act.
To cap a 13-play, 70-yard drive, he floated a pass into the back corner of the end zone to junior receiver Thomas Duarte for a 7-yard touchdown, the sixth time this season that he’s found the Mater Dei High product for a score.
“With Josh, you can never faze him,” Duarte said. “I don’t know what it is about him, but we all love it. Whatever happened on that last play, it doesn’t matter to him. He wants to play the next play and dominate.”
Duarte finished with career highs of 10 catches and 141 yards and the touchdown.
Rosen capped UCLA’s next drive with another scoring toss, hitting Devin Fuller along the sidelines as the senior receiver turned it into a 19-yard touchdown.
